div1.p: Gorgas reports to Kean that he will be receiving reinforcements shortly.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, January 14, 1918

January 14, 1918.
Colonel J.R. Kean, U.S. Army,
Hdqrs. Army Ambulance Service,
C/o French Army,
France.
My dear Kean:
div1.p:
Yours of December the 7th is acknowledged. Before you
get this letter I hope you will receive your ten sections and 300
extra men. They have been waiting now to sail for the past four
months; I would not be surprised, though, to get a cable bringing
them back from mid-ocean. The other 17 sections, I expect, will
sail in a day or two. This, as I understand, is all you want
at present. The other sections, some seventy in number, that
we have organized for France, the Secretary has ordered to go to
Italy and we expect them to start very shortly.

If the French will make up their minds as to what they want
the Secretary will be perfectly willing to organize seventy more
sections to replace these going to Italy and to let the French have
what was originally promised them. But I judge from your letter
that they do not want any more.

There would be no trouble about sending the men their cots if
you could get General Pershing to request them. As it is they
will not allow us to send cots.

Fisher and Shaw left for New York today, expecting to sail
tomorrow and they will be able to give you all the news; I have no
doubt you have seen Mason by this time.
Mrs. Gorgas joins me in wishes for a happy New Year.
